The families of American citizens kidnapped by Hamas militants in Israel say they want to focus international attention on the plight of their loved ones in captivity ‚Äî including a 3-year-old girl who the White House confirmed was taken into Gaza during the Oct. 7 terror attack.

In an exclusive interview with @lesterholtnbc, the girl‚Äôs great-aunt was joined by seven other families whose relatives were taken hostage during Hamas' assault on kibbutzim, a musical festival and homes across Israel‚Äôs south. They spoke as thousands of people from across the U.S. descended on the National Mall for a pro-Israel march.

Read more at the link in bio.

Family members of hostages trapped in Gaza tell Lester Holt how they feel about the Biden administration‚Äôs response to bringing home their loved ones.

Thousands of demonstrators gathered at the National Mall on Tuesday for a rally in support of Israel and against the antisemitism and bias incidents that have erupted in the U.S. since the start of the war.

Organizers of the event say they are not only calling for the return of hostages, but also want to underscore "Israel's right to remain free from violence and the right of Jewish communities in North America and around the world to live free from hate."

Read more at the link in our bio.

Monday was supposed to be the day Bettersten Wade would finally get a measure of peace.
Instead, she suffered another indignity.

Wade and her lawyers had arranged with Hinds County officials to exhume the remains of her son, Dexter Wade, who‚Äôd been struck and killed by a Jackson police officer and buried in a pauper‚Äôs field at the county penal farm without her knowing. They agreed on 11:30 a.m. Monday. Her lawyers said they spoke to a county attorney Sunday to confirm.

But when Bettersten Wade arrived at the penal farm at the appointed time, her son‚Äôs remains had already been dug up, put in a body bag and placed in the back of a Chevy Suburban. County officials said a public works crew had turned up earlier in the morning and removed the remains before anyone else arrived.

‚ÄúIt makes me feel like I don‚Äôt exist,‚Äù Bettersten Wade said. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter that I‚Äôm his mother. It didn‚Äôt matter to them. They act like that‚Äôs their child and they‚Äôre really the one who decides what happens to him. I didn‚Äôt have any rights or say.‚Äù

Dexter Wade‚Äôs funeral is scheduled for next week. 

Read more at the link in bio.

@lesterholtnbc sat down with 12 family members of hostages that are being held in Gaza. Liz Hirsh Naftali‚Äôs relative, a three-year-old girl, was taken after her parents were killed in Hamas‚Äô attack.

A man was arrested on suspicion of manslaughter Tuesday in connection with the death of professional ice hockey player Adam Johnson, whose neck was cut by a skate blade mid-game.

Nottingham Panthers player Adam Johnson was playing in a Champion cup game against the Sheffield Steelers on Oct. 28 when the incident happened. Johnson died in hospital due to a "fatal neck injury."

After Johnson's death, the English Ice Hockey Association, which governs the sport below the Elite League, said they would require all players in England to wear neck guards from the start of 2024.

Iceland has declared a state of emergency and evacuated all 3,400 residents from the coastal town of Grindavik, saying there is a ‚Äúsignificant likelihood‚Äù of a volcanic eruption in the coming days.

The Icelandic Meteorological Office reported intense earthquake swarms in the southwestern part of the country in recent weeks, likely tied to the movement of underground magma in and around the Reykjanes Peninsula. 

On Monday around 900 earthquakes had been detected since midnight, but their size and intensity were decreasing. Officials said ground deformation in the region has also slowed, which ‚Äúcan be an indication that magma is moving closer to the surface.‚Äù

Read more at the link in bio.

The boys' high school soccer team in the Maine city that was the site of a mass shooting more than two weeks ago has won the state title.

The Lewiston High School Blue Devils beat Portland's Deering High School Rams 3-2 on Saturday in the Class A state championship game.

The shootings at a bowling alley and a nearby bar on Oct. 25 in Lewiston killed 18 people and injured 13 others, making it the deadliest mass shooting in Maine history.

Read more at the link in the bio.

Scientists have developed a new toothpaste that shows potential to prevent severe allergic reactions in adults with peanut allergies.

An early-stage clinical trial tested whether 32 adults with peanut allergies could safely brush their teeth with the toothpaste, which contains trace amounts of peanut protein. The hope is that introducing small amounts of peanuts to the body over time will help the immune system get used to the allergen and reduce severe reactions.

Adults in the trial used the toothpaste once daily for about 11 months. At the end of the study, none of the participants experienced severe reactions or anaphylaxis ‚Äî an allergic response often characterized by difficulty breathing, swelling in the throat, pale skin, blue lips, fainting or dizziness.

Read more at the link in bio.

Taylor Swift made history when 2024 Grammy Awards nominations were announced, becoming the first person to be nominated in the song of the year category seven times in her career. The song that garnered this year's nod in that category was her hit, "Anti-Hero."

Swift also logged her sixth album of the year nomination for "Midnights." She's now tied with a music icon Barbra Streisand for the most nominations by a female artist in that category.

The megastar earned a total of six nominations, which also included nominations for record of the year, best pop solo performance and best pop/duo group performance.

Read more at the link in our bio.

Keke Palmer is accusing her ex-boyfriend, Darius Jackson, of physical and emotional abuse, writing in court documents that he has repeatedly attacked her, trespassed at her home and "became very frustrated" with their 8-month-old son. 

Palmer says the abuse happened throughout her two-year relationship with Jackson and did not stop after their breakup in early October.

A judge has granted Palmer a temporary restraining order while she seeks sole custody of their child.

Read more at the link in our bio.

Israel will implement four-hour pauses in fighting in parts of the northern Gaza Strip each day, White House National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby said.

An announcement will be made three hours before each pause and the Israeli military assured the U.S. there will be no operations in designated areas during those times, he told reporters in a briefing.

Kirby's comments came after the U.S. was said to be discussing with Israel and Qatar a possible proposal for a dayslong pause in the fighting, according to two foreign diplomats and a U.S. official. 

It is unclear how exactly these pauses will differ from current ones, which Israel has been implementing for the past several days. Israeli officials have said that the brief suspensions in fighting have been to allow Palestinian civilians in northern Gaza to move south.

Read more at the link in bio.
Vivek Ramaswamy and Nikki Haley shared a number of tense moments at the Republican primary debate, with the tension carrying over post-debate.

Republican presidential candidates competed with each other to show the most support for Israel, draw the hardest line on Iran and speak out the most aggressively about antisemitism at Wednesday's GOP presidential debate, while downplaying what Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis called ‚Äúso-called Islamophobia.‚Äù

All five candidates said they fully supported Israel‚Äôs military campaign against Hamas and would not do anything to rein in its bombing of Gaza, which has led to a worsening humanitarian crisis for Palestinian civilians.

He was not the target this time around.

NBC News live-tracked every attack, criticism and barb the candidates delivered Wednesday in Miami.

A question on TikTok comes as the popular video platform, which is owned by Chinese tech company ByteDance, has re-entered the crosshairs of politicians and national security officials. 

TikTok has been the subject of scrutiny for years because of concerns that people in China may access the personal data of American users.

Most recently, members of Congress and people in the tech industry have criticized TikTok because of pro-Palestinian content on the platform.

Nikki Haley used the time to answer a previous question unrelated to TikTok.

Get live updates at the link in bio.

After Vivek Ramaswamy criticizes American support for Ukraine‚Äôs fight against Russia, Nikki Haley says President Putin and Chinese President Xi are "salivating at the thought" that someone like Ramaswamy could become president of the U.S.

The Biden-Harris campaign is putting up 1,000 signs featuring the ‚ÄúDark Brandon‚Äù meme around the venue for the GOP presidential debate in Miami today, it said.

The meme is an online image of President Biden with red laser eyes, meant to portray the president as powerful. The name stems from the Republican rallying cry, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Go Brandon,‚Äù which is a euphemism for an expletive against Biden. But White House staffers began embracing the ‚ÄúDark Brandon‚Äù meme last summer, and the president‚Äôs re-election campaign has used it as an icon, too.

Follow live updates from the third Republican presidential debate at the link in bio.

Virginia Del. Danica Roem has made political history once again after winning a seat in the state Senate on Tuesday. She is the first out transgender person elected to Virginia‚Äôs upper chamber and only the second trans person elected to any state Senate in the United States, following Delaware‚Äôs Sarah McBride in 2020.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm grateful the people of Virginia‚Äôs 30th Senate district elected me to continue representing my lifelong home of western Prince William County and greater Manassas,‚Äù Roem said. 

‚ÄúThe voters have shown they want a leader who will prioritize fixing roads, feeding kids and protecting our land instead of stigmatizing trans kids or taking away your civil rights.‚Äù

Read more at the link in bio.

From his bedroom in Seattle, John Michael has been checking a red alert app in recent weeks to see whether any rockets have landed near his friend‚Äôs house in Tel Aviv or the kibbutz where he taught this summer. 

As the Israel-Hamas war enters its second month, some Jewish Americans are turning to an information source little known to non-Israelis: rocket alert apps.

The platforms, which have been around for nearly a decade and draw on real-time data from Israel‚Äôs Home Front Command, warn users of incoming rocket attacks sometimes just moments before they happen.

Read more at the link in bio.

Ohio voters have added the right to access abortion care to the state's constitution, NBC News projects ‚Äî another major political victory for abortion-rights advocates in the nearly 17 months since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade.

The passage of the Issue 1 ballot measure inserts language in the state constitution guaranteeing every person in Ohio the right ‚Äúto one‚Äôs own reproductive medical treatment, including but not limited to abortion,‚Äù and barring the state from ‚Äúburdening, penalizing or prohibiting‚Äù those rights ‚Äî though it specifies that abortion will remain prohibited after the point a doctor judges a fetus would most likely survive birth, with exceptions to protect the woman‚Äôs life or health.

Read more at the link in bio.

House lawmakers on Tuesday censured Rep. Rashida Tlaib, the sole Palestinian American in Congress, over her remarks and actions in response to the Israel-Hamas war.

Republicans have seized on Tlaib‚Äôs words and actions criticizing Israel, joining several Democrats in condemning a video she posted on social media showing protesters chanting ‚Äúfrom the river to the sea‚Äù ‚Äî a phrase that has been used by Hamas and that Jewish groups consider an antisemitic call for the elimination of Israel. 

Tlaib‚Äôs positions have divided Democrats, who are wrestling with how to respond to the new conflict in the Middle East.

Democrat Cherelle Parker, a former member of the Philadelphia City Council, has been elected the city‚Äôs next mayor, NBC News projects, which will make her the first woman to hold the office.

A deer leapt 20 feet and landed on a pristine white pickup truck ‚Äî minutes before the owner was about to sell it.

Scientists have discovered the oldest black hole yet, a cosmic beast formed a mere 470 million years after the Big Bang.

The findings, published Monday, confirm what until now were theories that supermassive black holes existed at the dawn of the universe. 

Given the universe is 13.7 billion years old, that puts the age of this black hole at 13.2 billion years.

Even more astounding to scientists, this black hole is a whopper ‚Äî 10 times bigger than the black hole in our own Milky Way.

Read more at the link in bio.

The Gaza Strip is becoming a ‚Äúgraveyard for children,‚Äù U.N. Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres said, as he called for an immediate humanitarian cease-fire and the unconditional release of all hostages being held by Hamas.

The U.N. Security Council failed again last night to agree on a resolution on the war, however.

Despite more than two hours of closed-door discussions, differences remained, with the U.S. calling for ‚Äúhumanitarian pauses‚Äù and many council members demanding a ‚Äúhumanitarian cease-fire.‚Äù

Yesterday, the U.N. launched a $1.2 billion humanitarian appeal to help 2.7 million Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank. According to the Gaza Health Ministry, more than 10,000 people, including more than 4,000 children, have been killed since the conflict began a month ago.

Read more at the link in bio.

It has been a month since the surprise Hamas terrorist attack that Israel says killed over 1,400 people and left 240 still held hostage in the Gaza Strip. 

More than 1.5 million people have been displaced in Gaza, and health officials there say more than 10,000 have been killed as Israel bombards the Palestinian enclave from the air and assaults it on the ground.

Some 1,400 candles were lit at Jerusalem‚Äôs Western Wall yesterday in tribute to victims. In Tel Aviv, another vigil took place in Habima Square, where empty beds were presented in memory of the hostages who remain held in the Gaza Strip.

Read more at the link in bio.
Thousands gathered in Washington, D.C., and across the world, over the weekend to call for an end to Israel‚Äôs continued bombardment of Gaza, where civilian casualties have been growing.

A week into the war between Israel and Hamas, Raed Odeh said his barber shop, Palestine Hair Salon, received a menacing phone call from an unknown number.

‚Äú‚ÄòWe‚Äôre going to come burn you. We‚Äôre going to burn your family,‚Äô‚Äù Odeh, a married father of five, said the caller threatened.

In places like Passaic County, which boasts a significant concentration of Palestinian Americans and has long been a hub in New Jersey for the more Conservative and Orthodox followers of Judaism, the bewildering events in the Middle East are being acutely monitored ‚Äî and exposing the delicate divisions among neighbors that resurfaced this past summer, prior to the war.

While residents stand firm that violence and bias are not welcome here, charged language on social media and the bloodshed overseas are exposing stark differences but also mutual concerns among Palestinian Americans and Jewish Americans in Passaic County who are navigating their circles with both pride and caution.

Hundreds of thousands of Afghans have left Pakistan in recent weeks as authorities pursue foreigners they say are in the country illegally, going door to door to check migrants‚Äô documentation. Pakistan set Oct. 31 as a deadline to leave the country or else they‚Äôd be arrested as part of a new anti-migrant crackdown.

Aid agencies said there is limited access to drinking water, no heating source other than open fires, no lighting, and no toilets. There is open defecation and poor hygiene. U.N. agencies and aid groups are setting up facilities with thousands of people entering Afghanistan every day.

"There are families who have nothing here, no land, no home. They are just living under the open sky. No one is helping,‚Äù said Kayal Mohammad, who was not allowed to take any belongings with him.

Kekoa Lansford can‚Äôt shake the images of glowing skeletons in burning homes and charred bodies in cars.

More than two months after a ferocious wildfire burned his West Maui community to the ground, killing at least 97 people, Lansford and other survivors say the trauma is as real now as the day it sent hundreds of people fleeing for their lives as flames chewed through their neighborhoods and thick, black smoke filled the skies.

‚ÄúYou just keep moving until you have time to process,‚Äù Lansford said. 

Some residents have reported trouble eating, sleeping, and experiencing nightmares.

Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia set a course record to win the New York City Marathon men‚Äôs race on Sunday while Hellen Obiri of Kenya pulled away in the final 400 meters to take the women‚Äôs title.

Marcel Hug won the men‚Äôs wheelchair race, the Swiss star‚Äôs record-extending sixth NYC Marathon victory.

Catherine Debrunner of Switzerland won her New York debut, shattering the course record in the women‚Äôs wheelchair race. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to describe in words. I said to my coach if I win this race, it‚Äôs the best performance I ever showed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúKnew it‚Äôs the toughest marathon of all. It was the first time. I knew it was going to be so tough.‚Äù

Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds will endorse Gov. Ron DeSantis (R-Fla.) for president at a rally in Des Moines on Monday, sources close to both governors told NBC News.‚Å†
‚Å†
Reynolds‚Äô endorsement is a major boost for the Florida governor, who‚Äôs gone all-in on Iowa since launching his bid for the GOP nomination in May. DeSantis currently trails former President Donald Trump by 27 points in the Hawkeye State, according to the latest NBC News/Des Moines Register/Mediacom poll.‚Å†
‚Å†
The endorsement is a major departure from tradition: Iowa governors have typically stayed on the sidelines ahead of the caucuses. ‚Å†

Every recovery room at Fundaci√≥n ILE, an abortion clinic in Mexico City, is equipped with a small bed, blankets, sanitary pads and a turquoise journal. 

The journals are filled with letters written by women minutes after having had abortions.

Some of them detail the reasons they chose to undergo the procedure. Others have messages of encouragement for the next women who will be in their position. 

Clinics like Fundaci√≥n ILE have been legal in Mexico City for 16 years, after a groundbreaking 2007 decision decriminalized abortion in the capital state. Other Mexican states have individually followed suit. Then, in September, the country's Supreme Court voted to decriminalize the procedure nationwide, marking a contrast to growing abortion restrictions in many U.S. states after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

But in a culturally conservative country where nearly 80% of the population identifies as Catholic and femicide is seen as a national emergency, Mexico‚Äôs Supreme Court ruling does little to quell the social stigmas that continue to drive the conversation around abortion and women‚Äôs reproductive rights. The next phase of the fight, advocates and experts say, is a process of ‚Äúsocial decriminalization‚Äù that can be even more challenging than the legal battles. 

Read more at the link in bio.

For the past week, 22-year-old Maria del Rosario Saravia has waited for news of her mother, two brothers and young son since she lost contact with them the night Otis, a Category 5 hurricane, devastated the Mexican coastal resort of Acapulco.

Saravia has been camped out on the Paseo del Pescador on Acapulco Bay desperately seeking news of her family after they were lost in the record-breaking storm that killed nearly 50 people and shattered livelihoods last Wednesday morning.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be here until we have found our relatives,‚Äù she said, speaking of her mother Maria Hilaria Delgado, 55, her 4-year-old boy Luis Alberto Lopez and brothers Luis Sebastian Herrera, 9, and Alejandro Marcelino Herrera, 31.

Saravia is one of dozens of people trying to locate loved ones since Otis slammed into Acapulco, severing communications and leaving the city of nearly 900,000 people without means of communication.

Read more at the link in bio.

The airstrike reduced more than a dozen buildings to rubble, killed dozens and wounded hundreds of people, according to local health officials.

The Israeli military says its attack on the Jabalia refugee camp a killed senior Hamas commander, who they said was an architect of the Oct. 7 terror attack.

Foreign passport-holders and critically injured residents were able to enter Egypt through the Rafah border crossing for the first time since Israel imposed a siege on the Gaza Strip.

Clutching suitcases and foreign passports, on stretchers and in strollers, civilians gathered in their hundreds to cross through the Rafah border into Egypt on Wednesday. They were the first to make it out of the Gaza Strip since Hamas‚Äô surprise terror attack and the ensuing Israeli bombardment and siege on the Palestinian enclave.

One man, his leg apparently amputated, said goodbye to his loved ones, accepting their kisses on his cheeks and forehead. A young boy cried in pain, his leg wrapped in bandages and encased in metal brace, waiting to be transported for urgent medical care on the other side.

Many foreign passport holders have lingered near the border since the first days of the war, pushed south by Israeli orders and drawn there by promises that the crossing might open for them to evacuate.

But the gates never opened to civilians ‚Äî until today.

Read more at the link in bio.

Javelina, pig-like creatures with big teeth, have been causing chaos at the Seven Canyons golf club in Arizona.

‚ÄúWhen you come upon them and see them, it‚Äôs like The Tasmanian Devil,‚Äù Seven Canyons general manager Dave Bisbee told CNN.

Scientists widely agree that an ancient planet, named Theia, likely smashed into Earth as it was forming billions of years ago, spewing debris that coalesced into the moon that decorates our night sky today.

But one glaring mystery at the center of this hypothesis has endured: What ever happened to Theia? Direct evidence of its existence has remained elusive. No leftover fragments from the planet have been found in the solar system.

A new theory, however, suggests that remnants of the ancient planet remain partially intact, buried beneath our feet.

The Israeli military forged ahead with its raid on Gaza‚Äôs largest hospital Wednesday afternoon, 12 hours after troops first stormed the complex, in a significant step that could shape the pace and extent of its war with Hamas.

The hospital, Al-Shifa, has become synonymous with Israel‚Äôs 40-day effort to wrest control of Gaza from Hamas. Its capture could affect international sentiment about the invasion as well as the continuing negotiations to free the hostages captured by Hamas last month.

A senior Israeli military official said on Wednesday that troops were interrogating people inside the hospital and had found weapons during the raid, but declined to provide evidence or further details because the operation was ongoing. Palestinian officials, the heads of United Nations agencies and some Mideast regional leaders condemned the raid, warning that it risked the lives of Gaza‚Äôs most vulnerable.

Few details about the raid were available on Wednesday afternoon, as communications were disrupted in Gaza City. This is a developing story. Tap the link in our bio for live updates.

Hochatown, on the shores of Broken Bow Lake in the southeast corner of Oklahoma, has a population of just 219 people. But on weekends, as many as 50,000 visitors, mostly from Dallas, flock there to kayak, fly-fish and hike among the waterfalls, rapids and thick forests of pine and pawpaw trees.

Before the Covid-19 pandemic, Hochatown had roughly 400 cabins for rent on Airbnb. There are now more than 2,400 ‚Äî a staggering 413% increase in five years. Hochatown does not have a single police officer or professional firefighter. There is no sewerage system, no garbage collection, not even sufficient water to handle the proliferation of people and new homes.

What might be called the Airbnb effect has transformed the landscapes ‚Äî and the economies ‚Äî of countless small towns across the U.S. Read the full story at the link in our bio. Photos by @shelby_tauber

Doctors have long relied on a few key patient characteristics to assess risk of a heart attack or stroke, using a calculus that considers blood pressure, cholesterol, smoking and diabetes status, as well as demographics: age, sex and race.

Now, the American Heart Association is taking race out of the equation.

The overhaul of the widely used cardiac-risk algorithm is an acknowledgment that, unlike sex or age, race identification in and of itself is not a biological risk factor.

Learn more about the revision, as well as a broader trend toward removing race from a variety of clinical algorithms within the U.S. health care system, at the link in our bio. Photo by Rocketclips, Inc./Alamy

A Volcano May Erupt in Iceland

Iceland is bracing for a possible volcanic eruption. Since late October, tens of thousands of earthquakes have been reported in the Reykjanes Peninsula, in the southwestern part of the country. At one point there were as many as 1,400 in a single 24-hour period.

On Tuesday, the Icelandic Met Office, the country‚Äôs weather service, warned that there was a ‚Äúsignificant likelihood of a volcanic eruption in the coming days.‚Äù The increased seismic activity and the formation of a nine-mile underground river of magma have led the authorities in recent days to declare a state of emergency and to evacuate the small fishing town of Grindavik, where more than 3,000 people live.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about what to expect in the event of a volcanic eruption in Iceland.

The U.S. has no coherent system for providing long-term elder care, leaving aging people to rely on a patchwork of solutions. Millions of families are facing daunting life choices and potential financial ruin as the escalating costs of care devour their savings and incomes.

The private market where a minuscule portion of families buys long-term care insurance has shriveled.  Labor shortages have left families searching for workers willing to care for their elders at home.The cost of a spot in an assisted-living facility has soared to an unaffordable level for most middle-class Americans who qualify for nursing home care paid for by the government only after they run out of money. 

The prospect of dying broke looms as an imminent threat for the boomer generation, which has vastly expanded the middle class and looked hopefully toward a comfortable retirement on the backbone of 401(k)s and pensions. The problem is only set to worsen: By 2050, the population of Americans 65 and older is projected to increase by more than 50%, to 86 million, according to census estimates. The number of people 85 or older will nearly triple, to 19 million.

The New York Times and @kffhealthnews, a nonprofit news organization, interviewed dozens of families and experts for the ‚ÄúDying Broke‚Äù series, a joint project on long-term care. Read more at the link in our bio. Photos by @shuranhuang, @arinyoon, @fremson and @willdeshazer

The letter, part of growing internal dissent over the administration‚Äôs support of the war, calls on the president to seek an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip and to push Israel to allow humanitarian aid into the territory. It is the latest of several protest letters from officials throughout the Biden administration, including three internal memos to Secretary of State Antony Blinken signed by dozens of State Department employees as well as an open letter signed by more than 1,000 employees of the U.S. Agency for International Development.

The letter, a copy of which was reviewed by The New York Times, began by denouncing the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, then urged Biden to stop the bloodshed caused by Israel‚Äôs retaliatory military campaign in Gaza. Read the full story at the link in our bio

Six trees made famous by the series ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù will be cut down in the coming weeks, officials in Northern Ireland said on Monday.

The trees are part of the Dark Hedges, an international tourist attraction for fans of the HBO series. The beech trees, which form an arch over a road with long branches that twist up to the sky, have become one of the most photographed spots in Northern Ireland, with hundreds of tourists visiting on some days.

The trees that make up the Dark Hedges, which sit on privately owned land, were planted by the Stuart family in the 18th century. There were originally about 150 trees, but today just 86 remain, with some having been damaged in storms or by rot.

The Gaza Strip‚Äôs hospitals ‚Äúmust be protected,‚Äù President Joe Biden said on Monday as Israeli troops battled to seize control of what Israel says is a Hamas command complex that lies below the enclave‚Äôs main medical facility, Al-Shifa Hospital.

Thousands of people fled Al-Shifa over the weekend as Israeli troops encircled it. On Monday, the World Health Organization warned of a ‚Äúdire and perilous‚Äù situation for patients. The health organization said in a statement that Al-Shifa ‚Äúis not functioning as a hospital anymore,‚Äù after having run out of fuel and water, putting the lives of patients at risk.

Around 53 million Americans are caregivers for a family member or friend with a health issue or disability, and nearly a third spend 20 or more hours a week in that role. Looking after a sick family member can mean putting your own life on hold, often with little recognition or outside support.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which calls caregivers the ‚Äúbackbone‚Äù of long-term home care in the U.S., has warned that caregivers face many risks, including anxiety, depression, chronic health conditions and financial strain. Yet experts said that many caregivers feel they cannot speak openly about their frustration and anger, and that it is important to normalize those feelings.

Read more about the quiet rage of caregivers ‚Äî and how some seek community support ‚Äî at the link in our bio. Photos by @markabramsonphoto

Gaza‚Äôs main hospital is ‚Äúno longer functioning,‚Äù according to the World Health Organization, which warned of a ‚Äúdire and perilous‚Äù situation for hundreds of patients and displaced people trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.

Dozens of corpses are decomposing at the Al-Shifa Hospital because there is no way to preserve or remove them, a head nurse and a health official said.

The hospital and other medical centers in Gaza City had been struggling for weeks to maintain operations as supplies of fuel and medicine dwindled. The Health Ministry, which is controlled by Hamas, said on Monday that Israeli military vehicles had advanced to the gates of the hospital complex.

Patients at Al-Shifa have been dying because of a lack of power, according to doctors and Gazan health officials. Jihan Miqdad, a head nurse in the emergency room at Al-Shifa, said in a phone interview on Monday that patients who were on life support in the intensive care unit were dying because there was no oxygen.

‚ÄúThe situation here is catastrophic in every sense of the word,‚Äù she said.

Israeli security officials say that Hamas has built a vast command complex under the hospital, making it a legitimate military target. Hamas has denied the allegations, as has Al-Shifa‚Äôs director, Dr. Mohammed Abu Salmiya, who has called them ‚Äúuntrue.‚Äù

A spokesman for the Gazan Health Ministry, Dr. ‚Äã‚ÄãMedhat Abbas, said in a phone interview that more than 100 bodies were lying in the hospital‚Äôs front yard, another 50 were inside and around 60 were in the morgue.

This is a developing story. For the latest updates go to the link in our bio.

Understanding the reality of Texas matters. With a population of over 30 million, the state is increasingly shaping the cultural and political direction of the country. Its economy is one of the largest in the world, growing faster than even the nation‚Äôs.

Texas has long been defined by demographic changes, particularly its expanding Hispanic population. But the nature of those changes, and how profound they have become, has often been misunderstood, even by those who follow the state closely.

The New York Times collected years of census data, analyzed migration patterns and traveled to communities across Texas to understand what is happening in the state ‚Äì the nation‚Äôs second most populous ‚Äì a place that offers an important window into the future of both national politics and the attempts to deal with questions of identity and diversity.

Read more about how Texas is changing at the link in our bio. Photos by @ddrios, @meridithkohut and @townsend.___

South Africa is the most industrialized African country and was once considered an economic success story. But it has one of the highest youth unemployment rates in the world: 61% of people aged 15 to 24 are unemployed. The overall unemployment rate is 33%, and for high school graduates it‚Äôs 35%.

If South Africa, which has the most developed economy in Africa, cannot create enough jobs, economists warn, then how are poorer countries on the continent going to generate opportunities for their booming youth populations?

In the Rockaways, a low-lying peninsula in Queens that separates the Atlantic Ocean from Jamaica Bay, life has long been shaped by the tides. High-tide floods are not caused by the weather but by the twice monthly alignment of the Earth, sun and moon. When there is a full or new moon, the sun and moon exert a gravitational pull that forces tides to swell.

But as climate change causes sea levels to rise, high-tide floods ‚Äî sometimes called nuisance floods or sunny-day floods because they can happen on clear days ‚Äî are likely to inundate more coastal neighborhoods across the five boroughs.

As high-tide floods become more frequent, New Yorkers are asking themselves: When does a place become unlivable? Tap the link in our bio to read more about the problem and how the city is responding. Photos by @dave_sanders

Army Ammunition Plant Is Tied to Mass Shootings Across the U.S.

Lake City Army Ammunition Plant in Independence, Missouri, was built during World War II and has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam.

In recent years, it has also pumped billions of rounds of military-grade ammunition into the commercial market, an investigation by The New York Times found, leaving the ‚ÄúLC‚Äù signature scattered across crime scenes, including the sites of some of the nation‚Äôs most heinous mass shootings.

The plant, operated by a private contractor with Army oversight, is now one of the country‚Äôs biggest manufacturers of commercial rounds for the popular AR-15, and it remains so even as the U.S. government supplies ammunition to Ukraine.

A vast majority of Lake City rounds sold by retailers have been purchased by law-abiding citizens, including hunters, farmers and target shooters. Some of those people are drawn to the ammunition because it‚Äôs made with the same materials, and often to the same specifications, as the military‚Äôs. Others see the rounds as authentic accessories for their tactical weapons and gear.

But more than one million pages of search warrants, police evidence logs, ballistics reports, forfeiture records and court proceedings compiled by The Times provide a sweeping accounting of how Lake City ammunition, once intended for war, has also cut a criminal path through towns and cities in nearly all 50 states.

Read more about the findings at the link in our bio.

Video by Ben Dooley, @claire_sandwich and @ekrhyne

Chelsie Hill was a champion dancer when a night in February 2010 changed her life. She was in a serious car accident that left her with severe spinal injuries and unable to move her lower body.

Hill is the founder of the Rollettes, a dance team formed in 2012 for women who use wheelchairs. They perform all over the country and host an annual empowerment weekend in Los Angeles for women with disabilities called the Rollettes Experience.

Reclaiming her story as both a dancer and a wheelchair user meant finding others like her. She achieved what she set out to do, creating an unrepentantly girlie sisterhood that supports others.

Read more about @chelsiehill and the @rollettes_la at the link in our bio. Photos by @magdawosinskastudio

Where do we go when we die? 

For these seven people, the answer is space. They have chosen to send their ashes, or a sample of their DNA, into orbit, to the moon or simply hurtling into space. They settled on their final wishes for different reasons: spiritual, pragmatic, romantic. Many consider it the culmination of a lifelong fascination with space exploration, the impulse to look up with wonder. Lemuel Patterson, 71 (Photo 1), has always been enraptured by space and wants to be buried up there.  For others, a space burial signals acceptance of the idea that, in the end, there may be only a void awaiting us. 

To read their stories, tap the link in our bio. Photos by @dina_litovsky

The new crop of e-cigarettes represents an about-face from the more subdued look of its predecessors. That has experts concerned.

The understated look associated with Juul has been supplanted by the rounded, vivid designs of Elf Bars and other brands, whose color schemes often correspond with their flavors. Some public health experts are concerned that these devices‚Äô playful appearance ‚Äî which is neatly in line with the maximalist aesthetic preferences of many members of Gen Z ‚Äî may offer appealing new cover for nicotine products.

Each Elf Bar contains as much nicotine as 590 cigarettes, according to one estimate. Doctors say that nicotine is especially addictive for young people, and research suggests that teenage vapers risk both immediate and long-term lung damage.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how these products are geared to catch the eyes of young people. Photo illustration and photos by @ok__mccausland

Vietnam is having a cable car bonanza. The country is home to four of the longest cable cars in the world, and some 26 cable car lines have been built in a dozen locations across Vietnam over the past two decades.

Vietnam‚Äôs abundance of mountains, jungles and islands makes cable cars a natural fit since they can be built faster, cheaper and with less environmental damage than roads. But the cable cars are typically parts of mass-tourism complexes, and some travelers, citizens and environmental activists see them as scars on the landscape and a symptom of rampant overdevelopment by powerful conglomerates. Environmentalists are also anxious over the vision for Cat Ba Island from the Sun Group, one of the communist country‚Äôs biggest real estate and tourism developers. The on-again, off-again plans include a network of cable cars, a resort, a golf course and a cruise ship port, all in an area designated by UNESCO as a Biosphere Reserve.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about this booming mode of transportation in Vietnam. Photos by @askmott

‚ÄòIs It Good Enough to Fool My Gallerist?‚Äô

David Salle, one of America‚Äôs most thoughtful painters, hoped an AI program could nourish creativity. For nearly a year, the painter has tried to defy conventional thinking about generative artificial intelligence by testing an AI program‚Äôs capacity to become a sophisticated creator of art.

Salle held weekly meetings with two technologists, Danika Laszuk and Grant Davis, who tailored a text-to-image model to the painter‚Äôs requirements, relying on descriptive prompts that generated images in the artist‚Äôs style. The New York Times observed three of their work sessions, tracking the algorithm‚Äôs progress over several months as it adopted more of Salle‚Äôs techniques and abandoned the bland photorealism that often limits other generative programs.

At times, Washington, D.C. can feel like a tale of two cities: politicians and temporary dwellers versus multigenerational residents fighting to hold on to their piece of the district.
 
Once known as ‚ÄúChocolate City‚Äù because of its predominantly African American population, Washington has seen its demographics shift dramatically in recent decades, bringing both positive and negative effects of gentrification. The second phase of the Wharf district, a $3.6 billion development, has contributed a new Pendry luxury hotel and splashy dining destinations, all set against the backdrop of skyrocketing living costs (only recently cooling), increased crime and ongoing questions of cultural identity. But even in this time of transition, Washington is still a hub of art, history and social justice leadership, and is home to many of the best free museums and monuments in the world.

With so much hinging on refilling the ranks, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army. Volunteer groups offering all-female training are supporting the effort.

About 43,000 women now serve in the Ukrainian military, according to the ministry of defense, an increase of about 40% since 2021, the year before Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion. After the invasion, the military abolished restrictions that kept women from roles such as machine gunner, tank commander and sniper, and lifted rules prohibiting women from driving trucks. The third Republican presidential debate on Wednesday devolved at times into brutal personal attacks as the five candidates onstage tried to discuss high-minded issues from the fate of Social Security to the role of America abroad between cutting asides and provocative insults.

Shell email accounts, phantom truckers, supply-chain fraud and one seriously bewildered cargo freight broker. This is the long, strange story of one stolen load of valuable cargo in the form of 55,000 rare Kit Kats.

On Wednesday, the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo in Washington, D.C., will say goodbye to a family of giant pandas. 

Mei Xiang and Tian Tian, and their 3-year-old cub, Xiao Qi Ji, are scheduled to be loaded into crates and driven in trucks to a FedEx Boeing 777 called the Panda Express. They will then be flown 19 hours from Dulles International Airport to China, where they will join about 150 other pandas in a lush nature preserve in the misty mountains of Sichuan Province.

Giant pandas have been a fixture in Washington since 1972, when China sent the U.S. two pandas after Patricia Nixon, the first lady, mentioned her fondness for pandas to China‚Äôs premier during the landmark visit she and Richard Nixon made to Beijing. But U.S.-China tensions have been rising for years, and now there is speculation that China is asking for the return of the pandas because of the diplomatic deep freeze. Now, only one zoo in the U.S. will have giant pandas, but they are expected to return to China next year.

A proposed marine sanctuary in California is facing challenges after a last-minute boundary change to accommodate a wind farm.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, a 7,573-square-mile area that would include 156 miles of coastline along central California, would limit offshore oil drilling, acoustic underwater testing and other activities. But the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has thrown a wrench into those plans. In an effort to allow for the development of an offshore wind energy project, NOAA has suggested shifting the sanctuary‚Äôs borders to remove a section of the coastline that includes Morro Bay and Morro Rock ‚Äî or Lisamu‚Äô, a site sacred to the Chumash that the tribe has been planning to make the hub of the sanctuary.

For more than a century, Lessie Benningfield Randle, one of the last known survivors of the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, has lived with the searing details of that spring. For decades, she has recalled the fire that ravaged her neighborhood, Greenwood, and the frantic trip with her grandmother to the safety of a fairground.

Randle‚Äôs 109th birthday is Friday. She was 6 years old when a white mob attacked Greenwood with indiscriminate violence that wrought death and destruction and erased much of the promise of economic stability for future generations. She and the only other known survivor, Viola Fletcher, 109, are united in a historic legal battle to force the City of Tulsa and others to answer for the massacre.

‚ÄúI would like to see justice. It‚Äôs past time. I would like to see this all cleared up and we go down the right road,‚Äù Randle said in an interview with The New York Times. ‚ÄúBut I do not know if I will ever see that.‚Äù

On Monday, a team of lawyers representing Randle, Fletcher and the estate of Fletcher‚Äôs younger brother, took what they consider to be the last legal step in their long quest for justice. The Golden Gate Bridge, a rare blend of form and function, stands as an engineering marvel, an emblem of Depression-era American muscle. But it has a darker legacy, too: About 2,000 people are known to have died by jumping off the bridge. The true tally is certainly higher, since not all jumps are witnessed and not all bodies are found. 

Such tragedies, officials hope, are mostly in the past. After decades of pleas to raise the rail, workers are nearly finished installing 3.5 miles of stainless-steel nets ‚Äî a ‚Äúsuicide deterrent system,‚Äù officials call it ‚Äî strung on both sides of the bridge, end to end. The nets, which are nearly invisible from a distance, were chosen to appease those worried about altering the bridge‚Äôs iconic look or obstructing its famous views. But the nets can be seen by anyone standing at the rail, hanging about 20 feet down and stretching about 20 feet out. They are taut, marine-grade stainless steel nets meant to withstand the Golden Gate‚Äôs combination of rain, wind, salt and fog.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the long fight to make the bridge safer. Photos by @jimwilson125 

If you are having thoughts of suicide, call or text 988 to reach the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline or go to SpeakingOfSuicide.com/resources for a list of additional resources.

For Donald Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.

His 91 felony charges in four different jurisdictions have not significantly hurt him among voters in battleground states. Yet he remains weaker than at least one of his Republican rivals, and if he‚Äôs convicted and sentenced in any of his cases, some voters appear ready to turn on him ‚Äî to the point where he could lose the 2024 election.

Trump leads President Biden in five key battleground states ‚Äî Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, according to the Times/Siena polls.

Donald Trump‚Äôs trial will continue Monday in a New York courtroom with him on the witness stand, part of a proceeding that threatens the business empire that underpins his public persona and that fostered his run for the White House.

New York‚Äôs attorney general, Letitia James, called Trump to the witness stand at his own civil fraud trial in Manhattan, where, under oath and under fire, the former president will try to convince a single skeptical judge ‚Äî not a jury ‚Äî that he played no role in the inflation of his net worth to defraud banks and insurers.

Privately, Trump has told advisers that he is not concerned about his time on the stand. He held preparation sessions when he was in New York attending the trial, according to people briefed on the matter. Trump is deeply, personally enraged by this trial ‚Äî and the fact that his children have had to testify, according to several people who have spoken with him ‚Äî and he may not be able to restrain himself on the stand.

Doctors and nurses in Gaza‚Äôs teetering hospitals, which are nearing collapse without electricity and basic supplies, say they must now decide which patients get ventilators, who gets resuscitated, or who gets any medical treatment at all. Switzerland dominated the wheelchair races. Catherine Debrunner easily won her first New York marathon in a time of 1:39:32, a course record. How U.S. Troops Were Harmed By Firing Their Own Guns

A secret U.S. offensive in 2016 and 2017 used an unusual strategy to fight the Islamic State. The plan: Put a minimal number of American troops on the ground and have them pound the enemy with relentless artillery fire. What no one foresaw was the devastating toll it would take on the troops who did the firing.

Research has started to reveal that as with hits in football, repeated blast exposure from firing heavy weapons may cause irreparable injury to the brain. It is a sprawling problem that the military is just starting to come to grips with.

Dave Philipps of The New York Times spoke to dozens of veterans experiencing mysterious, life-shattering mental and physical problems and investigated a type of brain injury that may have caused the problems.

Severe obesity is the fastest-rising subcategory among youth ‚Äî ‚Äúan epidemic within an epidemic,‚Äù as the American Academy of Pediatrics calls it.

Pictured here is 16-year-old Alexandra Duerte, who has been living with polycystic ovary syndrome and prediabetes since she was 10. Her doctor suggested bariatric surgery, an operation on the gastrointestinal tract that helps patients lose weight. Alexandra is one of the roughly 20% of children in the U.S. are living with obesity. Some can develop what were once considered adult illnesses: hypertension, diabetes, fatty liver disease. Obesity can also magnify mental-health problems.

How far should doctors go to treat obesity? Read the story at the link in our bio. Photograph by @kholoodeid.

More than 500 runners with disabilities and guides are participating in this year's New York City Marathon. Francesco Magisano is one of them: Sunday will mark the sixth time the 28-year-old, who lost his vision as a teenager, will run the race.

For Schulman, the inspiration to be a guide came during an encounter with an blind runner during a previous marathon. ‚ÄúI hear from behind: ‚ÄòBlind runner! Blind runner on your right!‚Äô and two guides guiding what I guess was a 50-something-year-old woman and they just really flew past me,‚Äù Schulman said.

The Battle of the Bridge is the biggest football game of the year in Lewiston and Auburn, cities separated by a river in Maine. This season‚Äôs matchup came almost exactly a week after a gunman began a shooting spree that killed 18 people and wounded 13 others.

Ozempic, and drugs like it, have transformed how doctors treat diabetes and obesity. Now, some psychiatrists are turning to the drugs to counteract the weight gain that often comes with nearly all antipsychotics and some drugs used to treat depression and anxiety.

Heyer. Bobby Knight, one of college basketball‚Äôs signature coaches and a singular personality renowned for his tempestuousness and hubris, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Indiana. He was 83.

His death was announced in a statement on his website. It did not give a cause.

Mercurial and volatile, Knight was among the most polarizing characters in American sports. He was a brilliant coach who sought out intelligent players, deployed a ferocious man-to-man defense, extolled the virtues of precision passing and preached the necessities of never-ending hustle. Known as a principled perfectionist and a master teacher, he was also a driven competitor for whom losing was agony and a relentless motivator whose chief tool, it often seemed, was the anger-fueled rant.

In recent weeks, the Pakistani government abruptly declared that all foreign citizens living in the country without documents must leave by Nov. 1. 

The 1.7 million Afghans living illegally in Pakistan have come under mounting pressure, according to human rights groups and migrants. So far, more than 70,000 Afghans have left. Landlords have evicted Afghan tenants, fearing large fines if they don‚Äôt. Employers have fired undocumented Afghan workers. The police have raided neighborhoods popular among Afghans, arresting those without paperwork.

Rights groups have condemned Pakistan‚Äôs actions, worried about the possibility that some Afghans could face persecution in Afghanistan for past ties to Taliban opponents. Meanwhile, Pakistani officials have established several deportation centers nationwide. Many Afghans have faced devastating decisions about whether to try to stay in a country where they are no longer welcome or return to one where they have not lived for decades.

Tap the link in our bio to read about the dilemma Afghans currently face in Pakistan. Photos by @eliseblchrd

Nearly three years into an experiment that proponents hoped would spark a nationwide relaxation of drug laws, many in Oregon have turned against the decriminalization initiative known as Measure 110, which passed with 58% support in 2020. ‚Å†

People sprawled on sidewalks and using fentanyl with no fear of consequence have become a common sight in cities such as Eugene and Portland. Business owners and local leaders are upset, but so are liberal voters who hoped decriminalization would lead to more people getting help. In reality, few drug users are taking advantage of new state-funded rehabilitation programs.‚Å†
‚Å†
Change appears likely. A coalition of city officials, police chiefs and district attorneys recently called on the state legislature to recriminalize hard drugs. A measure to do so is in the works for next year‚Äôs ballot. A recent poll found the majority of Oregonians support the idea.‚Å†
‚Å†
The fundamental problem, according to law-enforcement officers and researchers, is that the threat of jail time hasn‚Äôt been replaced with a new incentive for people struggling with addiction to seek treatment.‚Å†
‚Å†
Some 6,000 tickets have been issued for drug possession since decriminalization went into effect in 2021, but just 92 people have called and completed assessments needed to connect them to services, according to the nonprofit that operates the helpline. The only penalty for those who don‚Äôt call is a $100 fine, which is rarely enforced.‚Å†
‚Å†
Advocates of drug decriminalization blame Oregon‚Äôs continued problems on nationwide trends, including the rise of deadly fentanyl and increased homelessness.‚Å†
‚Å†
They say Measure 110 is already succeeding at one of its goals: keeping people out of the criminal-justice system for drug possession. About 4,000 people were arrested for drug offenses in Oregon in 2022, down from 11,000 in 2020.‚Å†

The white-collar labor market is softening to a point that companies are encountering an issue that would have been unthinkable in the era known as the Great Resignation. ‚Å†
‚Å†
These days, too few people are voluntarily leaving their jobs.‚Å†
‚Å†
Turnover has declined so steeply at some large employers that companies now find themselves over budget on certain teams, requiring leaders to weigh whether to postpone projects or to cut additional staff as the end of year approaches. Other bosses worry about how to keep star employees engaged when there are far fewer vacant positions internally, making it harder to move people into new roles.‚Å†
‚Å†
The decline in quitting would seem a welcome development for bosses who spent years bemoaning high levels of job-hopping and rapidly rising salaries. But some executives said they have been caught by surprise at how quickly the labor-market dynamics flipped, posing new challenges.‚Å†
‚Å†
Morgan Stanley had layoffs in recent months in part because of low attrition within the 80,000-person Wall Street firm, CEO James Gorman said on a call with investors in mid-October.‚Å†
‚Å†
Employers try to accurately predict how many staffers will quit in a given year to help set budgets for teams and establish hiring plans. Software company ServiceNow uses a machine-learning model to anticipate the number of employees it expects will step down each quarter. Voluntary turnover this year has fallen below levels forecast by those models, said Sarah Tilley, senior vice president of global talent. She didn‚Äôt cite specific figures, but attrition among top-performing employees in 2023 is less than half of what it was in 2022.‚Å†
‚Å†

Steffen‚Äôs frustration with the boarding process began with an unpleasant trip to the airport in Seattle, where he waited in many lines. He thought the last one, at the jet bridge, was unnecessary.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThere should be a solution to this‚Äîno matter how weird it might be,‚Äù the 48-year-old said.‚Å†
‚Å†
His annoyance, which you don‚Äôt have to be an astrophysicist to understand, led him to develop what he says is the optimal boarding strategy.‚Å†
‚Å†
Here‚Äôs how it works: The first person to board a single-aisle jet like a Boeing 737 is the passenger in the window seat of the last row. Say that‚Äôs 30A. The next person would be exactly two rows away in 28A, followed by 26A, 24A and 22A until the window seats in even rows on the right side were full. Next are the window seats in even rows on the left side: 30F, 28F, 26F and so on. Then come window seats in odd rows on the right and left starting from the back. The same patterns apply to middle seats and aisle seats until the last person on board plops into the front row.‚Å†
‚Å†
The idea is to reduce the probability of traffic jams. If the primary bottleneck of the boarding process is people waiting in the aisle, mostly because of how long it takes for others to load their luggage, Steffen‚Äôs fix maximizes the number of passengers stuffing their bags into overhead bins simultaneously. It takes a serial process (one at a time) and makes it parallel (several at a time).‚Å†
‚Å†
Steffen‚Äôs academic theories might be too idealistic to overcome the realities of the business, but it‚Äôs still worth exploring why they work.‚Å†

While anxiety, depression and other mental-health conditions started to climb among children before Covid, they soared during the isolation and disruption of the pandemic. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The increased demand for treatment exacerbated a shortage of available mental-health services. This has left desperate families pouring into emergency departments that legally can turn no one away. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The influx of young mental-health patients is overcrowding emergency departments and delaying treatment across the country at both specialized children‚Äôs hospitals and general hospitals. Major pediatric and emergency medicine organizations issued a public warning to hospitals and doctors in August, stating that the lack of space and available staff is forcing children who need psychiatric care to wait too long in E.R.s. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Andrea Teague, an oncologist in Santa Fe, N.M., has struggled to get help for her teenage daughter Iris, who suffers from depression and an eating disorder. The lone therapist Teague knew of in Santa Fe specializing in adolescent eating disorders had a six-month wait list. An Albuquerque program was temporarily closed. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Teague eventually found residential facilities, but it took weeks to get her in. After being discharged from one facility, Iris tried to kill herself. After a mental-health evaluation, Iris, who had just turned 18, was transferred to an adult psychiatric unit at an Albuquerque hospital, where she was discharged after five days with a treatment plan that would have required her to wait months for a psychiatrist.‚Å†
‚Å†
Teague used her medical connections to cobble together a treatment plan, which includes a local therapist and a dietitian from Colorado who helps her daughter remotely. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúShe was in a crisis that required relatively urgent intervention, where waiting meant putting her life in danger,‚Äù Teague said. ‚Å†

Joji Barris-Paster, daughter of legendary car customizer George Barris, has a collection of his greatest hits‚Äîfrom an original 1966 Batmobile to the Munster Koach originally designed for the 1960s show ‚ÄúThe Munsters.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Other cars designed by her father include the Lil Redd Wrecker, a build he made for the Redd Foxx TV show ‚ÄúSanford and Son,‚Äù and a hot rod mail carrier called the Zip Code Mail Truck. He also worked on the Macabre Mobile from the 1988 film ‚ÄúElvira: Mistress of the Dark.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Barris, aka the ‚ÄúKing of the Kustomizers,‚Äù started out in the 1950s and moved to Los Angeles when hid designs started gaining popularity. In the mid-1960s, a producer asked him to build a car for a new TV series called ‚ÄúBatman.‚Äù The studio gave him 15 days to build a Batmobile, Barris-Paster says.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWhen my father first saw the 1966 TV Batmobile coming out of the Bat Cave on the set, he thought: ‚ÄòYou can‚Äôt see the car. It‚Äôs too dark.‚Äô So he painted the red-orange stripes,‚Äù she said. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Today, Barris-Paster keeps some of her father‚Äôs show cars in a private space in Los Angeles and others at a shop in Ventura County, Calif., shown here. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWe do not drive these cars much, but when we take them to car shows or charity events, it amazes me the way people react to them,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThese cars bring so much joy, which is what drove my father to keep creating them.‚Äù‚Å†

Online shoppers‚Äîto add to the specters of shipping delays and front porch-theft‚Äîhave a new annoyance: accidentally ordering doll-size versions of things.‚Å†
‚Å†
Emma Platt, 41, a U.K.-based graphic designer, bought a set of coat hangers labeled as ‚Äúsmall‚Äù from the Chinese fashion site Shein for her part-time business selling secondhand children‚Äôs clothes.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI probably couldn‚Äôt fit anything but Barbie clothes on there,‚Äù Platt said of the mini hangers that arrived. ‚Å†
‚Å†
It turns out it‚Äôs not uncommon. Online marketplaces sell tiny pink cowboy hats. They also sell miniature pencil sharpeners, palm-size kitchen utensils, scaled-down books and itsy-bitsy camping chairs. Many of the minuscule objects aren‚Äôt clearly advertised.‚Å†
‚Å†
Shoppers have gotten lazy when clicking ‚Äúbuy‚Äù and assume‚Äîoften wrongly‚Äîwhat size they‚Äôre getting, said Brendan Witcher, a principal analyst at research and advisory firm Forrester. But there is no doubt some online sellers deliberately trick customers into buying smaller and often cheaper-to-produce items, he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
Common tactics include displaying products against a white background rather than in room sets or on models, or photographing items with a perspective that makes them appear bigger than they really are. Dimensions can be hidden deep in the product description, or not included at all.‚Å†
‚Å†
In those instances, the duped consumer ‚Äúmay say, well, it‚Äôs only $1, $2, maybe $3‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the harm?‚Äù Witcher said. When the item arrives the shopper may be confused, amused or frustrated, but unlikely to complain or demand a refund.‚Å†

As the cost of having fun goes up, so do the odds that you‚Äôll feel let down.‚Å†
‚Å†
The cost of admissions and fees for entertainment rose faster than the cost of many staple goods last year, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. That has helped raise standards for the amount of fun we expect for our money‚Äîand triggered quick disappointment when our experiences don‚Äôt live up to the price. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Someone who scores cheap flights to Europe may give the trip five stars before the plane even boards. Someone who spends half their paycheck on playoff tickets may get cranky about it by halftime. ‚Å†
‚Å†
And people are spending for now. Corie Barry, Best Buy‚Äôs CEO, said at a conference last month that ‚Äúexperiences are really where people are willing to pay‚Äù and that this was dragging on demand for expensive electronics. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Studies on money and happiness tell us that paying for experiences tends to bring us greater pleasures than buying stuff, because those experiences can deliver payoffs before, during and after they happen. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Dissatisfaction is more likely when money is tighter, a 2022 study in the Journal of Consumer Research found. People feel worse about purchases of both things and experiences and write more negative reviews, researchers found. This regret often stems from thinking about all the other ways the money could have been used instead.‚Å†

The armies of people who make clothes for Western brands‚Äîsome of the lowest-paid factory workers in the world‚Äîare protesting for better wages, a sign that the era of ultracheap labor, and ultracheap clothes, on which many companies rely is increasingly under strain.‚Å†
‚Å†
Garment workers in Bangladesh make as little as $3 a day, or about $75 a month. In recent days, tens of thousands have refused to work, calling for the minimum wage to be raised to nearly three times that amount. Demonstrations have spiraled, with factories set ablaze and machines smashed. Some three hundred factories stopped operations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sewing operator Hamim Shikder, who joined protests, said the roughly $125 a month he earns‚Äîafter 50 hours of overtime‚Äîis spent on his son‚Äôs school fees, increasingly expensive groceries and other essentials. When his wife recently got sick with dengue he had to borrow money for medical bills. ‚ÄúWhatever amount I get, I have to spend,‚Äù he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
The core of the protests, that workers need higher wages to make even a basic living, has drawn widespread support, including from fashion giants H&M, Gap and Zara-parent Inditex, which source from the country. But no one can agree on who should foot the bill.‚Å†
‚Å†
Factory owners in Bangladesh say that for them to hike wages in a big way, Western brands that are their top buyers need to pay more for clothes. Although the big names in fashion publicly support higher pay, in practice they balk when costs go up and threaten to shift their orders to other countries, said Faruque Hassan, president of the Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association.‚Å†
‚Å†
Western brands say they support a boost in Bangladesh‚Äôs minimum wage, but most haven‚Äôt said by how much. Workers sewing clothes for them often make substantially more than the minimum wage but far less than what unions are demanding and what international organizations that benchmark living-wage standards consider to be enough.‚Å†

The U.S. has a lot of problems that desperately need solving. These aren‚Äôt Republican or Democratic challenges. They are American challenges. They affect every one of us, and we need to face them together, writes @joemanchin for @wsjopinion.

There are enough votes in Congress to solve or at least make headway against every one of these problems. A genuine commitment to legislating would put America on firmer footing for the next 20 years. But the Democratic and Republican machines have no interest in solutions. Instead, they stoke outrage because doing so brings them fame and funding.

Today, the business of politics is about monetizing anger and getting paid for it. And business has never been better. Not for me.

I have made one of the toughest decisions of my life and decided that I won‚Äôt run for re-election to the Senate. I am proud of having worked every day of the past 42 years trying to make things better in the Mountain State. But this moment in the nation‚Äôs history is so filled with peril and political dysfunction that I want to work not only for my beloved West Virginia but for all Americans. Working together, I want to eliminate what is standing in the way of so many obvious and popular solutions.

While the Democratic and Republican parties increasingly cater to the extremes, most Americans are moderate, levelheaded folks, and they are plain worn out. We need to reaffirm that country should always come before party.

Hundreds of thousands of migrants from all over the world are making their way to the Southwest U.S. border, with American and Mexican authorities reporting a surge in apprehensions of people from Asia and Africa as human smuggling networks widen their reach across the globe.‚Å†
‚Å†
Arrests at the Southwest U.S. border of migrants from China, India and other distant countries, including Mauritania and Senegal, tripled to 214,000 during the fiscal year that ended in September from 70,000 in the previous fiscal year, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection data. Fewer than 19,000 migrants from Asia and Africa were apprehended in the fiscal year ended September 2021.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThese days, we are dealing with 120 nationalities and 60 different languages,‚Äù said Enrique Lucero, head of the migrant support unit of the Tijuana city government, across from San Diego.‚Å†
‚Å†
Travelers say they exchange information and share videos of U.S.-bound routes on Tik Tok and Facebook, while smugglers offer lodging and travel agencies advertise transport services. Most Asian and African migrants make multiple airport stopovers in what are coming to be known as ‚Äúdonkey flights‚Äù to reach countries such as Brazil, Ecuador or Nicaragua, which have few or no visa requirements for some nationalities. Once they set foot in Latin America, they move north in buses or cars and stay at hotels booked by smuggling organizations.‚Å†
‚Å†
For the second year in a row, arrests by the Border Patrol at the U.S. Southern border surpassed two million. Most of them, almost nine out of 10 apprehensions, are of migrants from Latin America and the Caribbean. But the surge in so-called extracontinental migrants poses a challenge for the U.S. because deporting migrants to Africa and Asia is time-consuming, expensive and sometimes not possible.‚Å†

As Hamas launched its deadly assault on Israel nearly a month ago, the mastermind of the Islamist militant group‚Äôs attacks incited Arab citizens of Israel to ‚Äúkill, burn and destroy‚Äù their Jewish neighbors.‚Å†
‚Å†
Instead, Awad Darawshe helped those wounded in Hamas‚Äôs violent rampage. ‚ÄúIt cost him his life,‚Äù said his sister, Raya Darawshe.‚Å†
‚Å†
The 23-year-old Arab citizen of Israel was working as a medic at an all-night music festival in southern Israel on the morning Hamas militants broke out of the Gaza Strip, killing 1,400 people and taking more than 240 others hostage.‚Å†
‚Å†
While terrified revelers fled, Darawshe stayed to treat the victims and was shot by Hamas, becoming one of more than a dozen Arabs who were killed or captured in the wide-scale attacks.‚Å†
‚Å†
Their deaths illustrate the dilemma facing members of the country‚Äôs Arab minority, as war between Israel and Hamas pulls them between their country and their kin. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Hundreds of thousands of Palestinian Arabs were driven from their homes during the war that erupted upon the creation of the state of Israel in 1948. Those who remained and their descendants‚Äîcolloquially called ‚Äô48 Arabs‚Äîmake up about 20% of the population and are dubbed Arab-Israelis by the state. They have largely sought integration in Israel and enjoy equal rights on paper, but many say they feel like second-class citizens.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWhenever there is a war or anything, it comes back against us as ‚Äô48 Arabs,‚Äù said Darawshe‚Äôs sister.‚Å†
‚Å†
The backlash demonstrates the fragile standing of Israel‚Äôs sizable Arab population‚Äîa group that says it is being found guilty by association, even while counting its members among victims of Hamas‚Äôs horrifying attack. ‚Å†

On the wall of the border crossing between bombed-out Gaza and Egypt‚Äôs Sinai desert there is a list. The names on it have been a source of hope, despair and confusion for the hundreds of foreign families wanting to escape the Palestinian enclave under Israeli fire.‚Å†

When movements such as #MeToo or Black Lives Matter came into the national spotlight, companies took broad stands against sexism or racism, issuing forceful statements and organizing candid conversations. The muted discussion around the Israel-Hamas conflict is a sharp turn. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Employees are criticizing their companies‚Äô responses as tepid or tardy, and saying they feel as though leaders want to avoid the subject.‚Å†
‚Å†
Jewish employees such as Alyssa Bleser, chief legal officer at a cannabis company, say they‚Äôre troubled by rising antisemitism and feeling alienated and unsupported by the lack of response from co-workers and bosses. ‚ÄúI would like to see my non-Jewish colleagues and friends speak up,‚Äù says Bleser.‚Å†
‚Å†
After her 11-year-old daughter was told by a classmate that she and other Jews should die, Bleser emailed her CEO a statement she‚Äôd written in support of Israel, suggesting he circulate it among investors. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The CEO, Jonathan Morrison, didn‚Äôt circulate the statement but later invited Bleser and her husband to discuss the conflict. He says he prefers to show support to his Jewish colleagues one-on-one, adding that it feels more meaningful that way.‚Å†
‚Å†
Many company leaders are taking a similar route, given the fraught, complex history between Israel and the Palestinians and the sense that there is no right thing to say. ‚ÄúCEOs, they‚Äôre like, nuh-uh, not getting dragged into this one,‚Äù says Johnny C. Taylor Jr., head of the human-resources professional association SHRM.‚Å†
‚Å†
Speaking out at work, or outside it, can exact a professional toll, workers say. Some people who‚Äôve shared views publicly have lost jobs. Workers from California to Chicago say in interviews that they believed they‚Äôve been reported to their employers for voicing pro-Palestinian sentiment online. ‚Å†

When girls at Westfield High School in New Jersey found out boys were sharing nude photos of them in group chats, they were shocked, and not only because it was an invasion of privacy. The images weren‚Äôt real.‚Å†
‚Å†
Students said one or more classmates used an online tool powered by artificial intelligence to make the images, then shared them with others. The discovery has sparked uproar in Westfield, an affluent town outside New York City.‚Å†
‚Å†
Digitally altered or faked images and videos have exploded along with the availability of free or cheap AI tools. While celebrity likenesses from Oprah Winfrey to Pope Francis have drawn media attention, the overwhelming majority of faked images are pornographic, experts say.‚Å†
‚Å†
The lack of clarity on such images‚Äô legality‚Äîand how or whether to punish their makers‚Äîhas parents, schools and law enforcement running to catch up as AI speeds ahead.‚Å†
‚Å†
Some Westfield parents said their daughters have felt humiliated and powerless, and worry about damage to the girls should the images surface later. And they are upset that no resolution is forthcoming.‚Å†
‚Å†
Even among parents, there is no consensus. Some called for harsh punishment for whoever created the images. Others deemed it a youthful transgression that should be forgiven.‚Å†
‚Å†
The debate and its aftermath are likely to continue for months. Westfield police are investigating, and a state senator has asked county prosecutors to look into the case.‚Å†

Ittai Gradel, an academic‚Äìturned‚Äìgem dealer in Denmark, was trawling eBay a decade ago when he thought he had stumbled across a gold mine.‚Å†
‚Å†
Gradel saw a seller advertising a glass gem from the 19th century. Gradel immediately recognized it as something much more valuable: an agate Roman Medusa cameo from the second century. He snapped it up for ¬£15 plus postage, then turned around and sold it to a collector for a couple of thousand pounds.‚Å†
‚Å†
In the following years, the same seller kept unearthing incredible finds at rock-bottom prices. Gradel inquired as to how he had come across these items. Then, in 2016, the seller posted a piece on eBay by mistake. Intrigued by the item, Gradel screenshotted it. But the seller quickly removed it from the website and said that it actually belonged to his sister, who didn‚Äôt want to sell it. ‚Å†

Gradel thought not much more about it. But in 2020, he came across an image on the British Museum‚Äôs website that showed the exact same item in its collection. Furthermore, the color photograph was recent. It suddenly dawned on Gradel: There was a thief in the British Museum. ‚ÄúAnd he was likely still within the walls,‚Äù he says.‚Å†

So began an antiques whodunit that has shaken the premise behind the museum‚Äôs most important reason for existing: that it is the best place to safely house some of the world‚Äôs greatest treasures. ‚Å†

In the fall of 2021, a consultant named Arturo Bejar sent Meta Platforms Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg an unusual note.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI wanted to bring to your attention what l believe is a critical gap in how we as a company approach harm, and how the people we serve experience it,‚Äù he began. Though Meta regularly issued public reports suggesting that it was largely on top of safety issues on its platforms, he wrote, the company was deluding itself.‚Å†
‚Å†
The experience of young users on Meta‚Äôs Instagram‚Äîwhere Bejar had spent the previous two years working as a consultant‚Äîwas especially acute. In a subsequent email to Instagram head Adam Mosseri, one statistic stood out: One in eight users under the age of 16 said they had experienced unwanted sexual advances on the platform over the previous seven days.‚Å†
‚Å†
For Bejar, that finding was hardly a surprise. His daughter and her friends had been receiving unsolicited penis pictures and other forms of harassment on the platform since the age of 14, he wrote, and Meta‚Äôs systems generally ignored their reports‚Äîor responded by saying that the harassment didn‚Äôt violate platform rules.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI asked her why boys keep doing that,‚Äù Bejar wrote to Zuckerberg and his top lieutenants. ‚ÄúShe said if the only thing that happens is they get blocked, why wouldn‚Äôt they?‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
For the well-being of its users, Bejar argued, Meta needed to change course, focusing less on a flawed system of rules-based policing and more on addressing such bad experiences. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI am appealing to you because I believe that working this way will require a culture shift,‚Äù Bejar wrote to Zuckerberg‚Äîthe company would have to acknowledge that its existing approach to governing Facebook and Instagram wasn‚Äôt working.‚Å†
‚Å†
Two years later, the problems Bejar identified remain unresolved, and new blind spots have emerged. The company launched a sizable child-safety task force in June, following revelations that Instagram was cultivating connections among large-scale networks of pedophilic users, an issue the company says it‚Äôs working to address.‚Å†
‚Å†
